member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.MarkerConditionBase.CheckCondition(GraphicsServer.GSNet.SeriesData.Series,System.Int32,GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.MarkerType)
member.summary:
Override this method to provide custom criteria checking.
CheckCondition is called for each data point within the SeriesDrawing(s) object to which the marker condition object is associated. CheckCondition should return true if the data point passes the criteria of the check. If there are multiple marker condition objects associated to a SeriesDrawing object then the data point is passed into each object starting at the front of the marker condition object list (see ). Once one of the marker condition objects return true the check is halted for that data point.
member.param: The that contains the data that will be checked.
This int defines which data point within the series holds the data values to check.
This is the used to draw the series. The check may need to access data from a differnet within the series based on the MarkerType.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.MarkerConditionBase.MarkerFill
member.summary: This property provides access to the protected propBackground Background object. Note that developers can override this property if desired.
member.remarks: An important note to remember is that this Background object is referenced by each data point that passes the criteria of this object. This means that cooresponding markers will all paint the same.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.IPropertyPage
member.summary: All property pages displayed via the methods implement the IPropertyPage interface. These interface methods are used to keep all property pages sychronized with the page being modified by the user.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.IPropertyPage.UpdatePage
member.summary: Called by the property sheet dialog in response to the active property page calling the method in the class, which hosts all the property pages.
member.remarks:
Note that this method will get called when your property page is inactive due to another property page modifying properties. If your property page is modifying properties that other pages modify, then use this method to check to see if any of your cached property values have been modified and then refresh these values.
Also note that anytime a user modifies a value on your property page you should call the method in the property sheet dialog. This will notify all other pages that values have changed.

member.remarks: Use this method to cache references to the passed in parameters.
member.param: The chart object that is being modified by the property page.
The property sheet dialog that is hosting the property page.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.OleDBConnect
member.summary: The OleDBConnect object is a design time object. Its purpose is to allow the user, in design time, to create a connection to an OleDb datasource. Once a connection is created, and there are SeriesDrawing objects in the the SeriesDrawingList, the user can then connect the fields in the OleDb connection to components in the SeriesDrawing objects via the FieldSource property.
member.remarks: Note that this design time object allows only a single OleDb connection to exist. Behind the scenes, an OleDBDataProvider object is allocated to provide this access. If you require multiple connections, you can create multiple OleDBDataProvider objects directly in the code behind pages.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.OleDBConnect.ConnectString
member.summary: This property contains any valid OleDb connection string. See the OleDB references for proper connection string syntax.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.OleDBConnect.SelectString
member.summary: This property contains the selection string used by an OleDB data source. See the OleDB references for proper select string syntax based on the chosen OleDB data source type.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.OleDBConnect.FieldSource
member.summary: The purpose of the FieldSource property is to allow the user to pop up the field source dialog, which displays a list of existing Series objects (that live in the existing SeriesDrawingList wrapped inside of SeriesDrawing objects). When a Series object is selected in this dialog, the user can then enter field names from the OleDb connection into the various components for the series.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.PaletteType
member.summary: Enumerates the preset color palettes that can be applied to SeriesDrawing objects in the chart.
member.remarks: Setting a palette via this enumeration empties the colors from the SeriesDefault.MarkerColorList and then populates the MarkerColorList with colors from the specified palette. After the list has been populated, the colors in it can be modified.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDefaults
member.summary: Encapsulates and applies default property settings to each SeriesDrawing object that is created when a new series is added to the chart.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDefaults.SetDefaultSeriesDrawingProperties(GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing,System.Int32,GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.ChartType)
member.summary: Apply the SeriesDefaults object to an existing SeriesDrawing object.

remarks.para: If the current setting of the SeriesDefaultsEnabled property is True, this method applies the defaults set in the SeriesDefaults objet to to the provided SeriesDrawing object.

Note that ChartType is one of the parameters for this method. That is because the method must know the ChartType when setting the default properties to produce a readable chart. For example, if the ChartType is Scatter2D and the SymbolsOn property is set to false, then this method ignores the SymbolsOn property. Otherwise you would not see any of the scatter symbols.

member.param: The SeriesDrawing object for which to set the default properties.
The index of the SeriesDrawing object in the series list. This is a 0 based index.
The ChartType of the chart that will display the SeriesDrawing.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDefaults.PaletteType
member.summary: Fills the MarkerColorList with a palette of colors.
member.remarks: Once a palette has been selected, the user can go to the MarkerColorList property and add, delete or modify any color that has been placed in the list by the palette selection.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDefaults.MarkerColorList
member.summary: Gets a ColorList object that maintains an array of colors that will be applied to SeriesDrawing objects.
member.remarks:
Colors in the list are applied, in turn, to each SeriesDrawing object in the chart's SeriesDrawingList and to each new SeriesDrawing object that is added to the chart. The first color in the MarkerColorList is applied to the first SeriesDrawing object in the chart's SeriesDrawingList, the second color to the second SeriesDrawing object, and so on.This list of colors is modified whenever a predefined PaletteType is selected. After selecting a palette, you can add, delete, or modify colors in the MarkColorList.
If the list is empty, a default set of colors is used.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDefaults.SeriesDefaultsEnabled
member.summary: Controls whether property settings for the SeriesDefaults object are applied as new SeriesDrawing objects are added to the chart.
member.remarks:
If set to true, the properties defined within the SeriesDefaults object are applied to each series as the series is added to the chart.
Note: Setting this property to false does not disable either the PaletteType property or the MarkerColorList property.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing

summary.para: Supports the visual display of data on a chart. For example, you can use the MarkerType property of a SeriesDrawing object to select whether datapoints are represented by lines or bars or by some other marker. You can use the MarkerLabelsOn property to display labels for datapoints. And you can use the SetUserMarkerLabel() method to override the default label for a particular data point.

member.remarks:
Nothing that you do to a SeriesDrawing object has any effect on the underlying data. In Graphics Server .NET, data is stored in a Series object and the display characteristics for the data are stored in a separate SeriesDrawing object. When a Series object is added to a chart, a SeriesDrawing object is allocated and the Series object is placed inside it. The SeriesDrawing object then exposes properties and methods that control how the Series object's data is displayed when the chart renders. Once the SeriesDrawing object has been allocated, it is placed inside the chart object's SeriesDrawingList property, which, as the name implies, simply lists the SeriesDrawing objects associated with the chart.
Series objects (which contain data for a series) are independent of SeriesDrawing objects (which contain display characteristics for data). You can add the same Series object simultaneously to several charts. In each case, the Series object will be encapsulated by a different SeriesDrawing object, which may or may not have different display characteristics from all the other SeriesDrawing objects that are associated with the same data. Thus one set of data can be rendered differently on many different charts.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.#ctor

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.GetDataPointMarkerFill(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the Background object that is the marker fill for the specified data point.
member.remarks: Note that this method never returns a null value. It will return a background object from one of three places. The method first checks to see if a marker condition set a background for the data point. If not, then it checks the user override background list for a data point override. Finally, if no background has been found, it returns the background in the MarkerFill property.
member.param: Index of data point to retrieve.
member.returns: Background object.

member.remarks: Note that this method never returns a null value. It will return a Line object from one of two places. The method first checks to see if a line condition exists and is true for the data point. If not, it returns the Line in the MarkerLine property.
member.param: Index of data point to retrieve.
member.returns: Line object.

member.summary: Gets the Background object that controls how markers will be filled when rendered on a chart.

See the class for detailed information about background properties.

members.member:
Gets the Background object that controls how Gantt bars are filled when the percent completion value has been set for the bar.
See the class for detailed information about background properties.
Background Class

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.MarkerLabelProperties
member.summary: Gets the TextPainter object that controls how marker labels are displayed if marker labels are turned on.
member.remarks: See the class for more information on TextPainter properties.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.MarkerLabelGap
member.summary: Sets and gets the gap between the marker and the marker label.
member.remarks:
Increase this number for a larger gap.
For pie charts this value is only used when the property is set to PieLabelLocation.Outside. In this case the marker label gap is the space between the tip of the line and the text.
Smart pie labels do not use this property. Instead they use the property.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.MarkerLabelsOn
member.summary: Controls whether or not markers for datapoints are labeled.
member.remarks:
If set to true, displays labels near the data pointer for a marker. Note, however, that each type of marker decides the best location for displaying the label.
The format of a marker label is controlled by the LabelFormatMask property of the axis to which the marker label corresponds.
The marker label for a specific data point can be overridden by the user via the SetUserMarkerLabel() method. See that method for further information.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.ColorCloseHigher
member.summary: Sets and gets the color to paint the rectangle on a High/Low/Open/Close chart when the close value is greater than the open value.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.ColorCloseLower
member.summary: Sets and gets the color to paint the rectangle on a High/Low/Open/Close chart when the close value is less than the open value.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.TickWidthHigh
member.summary: Width of the High tick on a High/Low/Open/Close chart.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.TickWidthLow
member.summary: Width of the Low tick on the High/Low/Open/Close chart.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.TickWidthOpen
member.summary: Width of the Open tick on the High/Low/Open/Close chart.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.TickWidthClose
member.summary: Width of the Close tick on the High/Low/Open/Close chart.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.CandleStickBoxWidth
member.summary: Width of the box on a candlestick marker.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.SymbolsOn
member.summary: Turns data point symbols on and off.
member.remarks:
A symbol is not the same as a marker. For example, a data point in a bar chart may have a bar marker that draws from the data point down to the X axis. If symbols are turned on, then a symbol will also display at the top of the bar marker centered around the data point. Different marker types determine the best location for displaying symbols when they are turned on.
Note that scatter charts do not actually display markers. Instead, they display symbols only. The marker in this case is an invisible rectangle around the data point and the symbol.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.LinesOn
member.summary: Turns connecting lines between data points on and off.
member.remarks: This property applies only to certain types of data markers. For example, line markers have the ability to display connecting lines, sticks and symbols. All three of these features can be turned on and off when displaying a series as a line marker.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.SticksOn
member.summary: Turns drop lines on and off for certain marker types.
member.remarks: Drop lines, or "sticks," can sometimes help the viewer's eye relate a data point to a value on the axis.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.MarkerType
member.summary: Sets and gets the marker type to use when displaying the data points for a series.
member.remarks:
When a new series is added to a chart, the value for the MarkerType property of the corresponding SeriesDrawing object defaults to CurChartType, which selects the default marker for the currently active chart type. You can customize the series by setting MarkerType to another value.
It is possible, with some chart types, to select a different marker for each series displayed on the chart. For example, most 2D X/Y linear charts allow a mixture of bar, line, stick, scatter, and area markers.
Be aware, however, that the marker type you select might not be supported by the currently active chart type. For example, ChartType.Line2D does not support MarkerType.Pie. If you select a marker type that is not supported by the current chart type, then the series will not render on the chart.
See the enumeration for information on supported marker types.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.Symbol
member.summary: Gets the Symbol object that controls the painting of symbols when they are turned on.
member.remarks: See the class for more information. Also, see the SymbolsOn property for a discussion of how markers and symbols differ.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.MapToXPrime
member.summary: Controls whether data points in the series map to the X prime axis.
member.remarks: If true, the series maps to the X prime axis. This will cause the X values of the data points to display in relationship to the scale of the X prime axis.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.MapToYPrime
member.summary: Controls whether data points in the series map to the Y prime axis.
member.remarks: If true, data points in the series map to the Y prime axis. This will cause the Y values of the data points to display in relationship to the scale of the Y prime axis.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.MapToYList
member.summary: Controls whether the Y values of data points in the series map to an axis in the AxisYList.
member.remarks: Defaults to -1, which indicates that the series should map to the primary Y axis. To map to a Y axis in the AxisYList, set the MapToYList property to the value of the target axis's index in the AxisYList.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.MapToYPrimeList
member.summary: Controls if the data points in the series will map to a different Y Prime axis in the AxisYPrimeList.
member.remarks: Defaults to map to the main AxisYPrime.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.MapToXList
member.summary: Controls if the data points in the series will map to a different X axis in the AxisXList.
member.remarks: Defaults to map to the main AxisX.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.MapToXPrimeList
member.summary: Controls if the data points in the series will map to a different X Prime axis in the AxisXPrimeList.
member.remarks: Defaults to map to the main AxisXPrime.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.SeriesName
member.summary: Gets and sets the display name for the SeriesDrawing object.
member.remarks:
The display name appears in the legend.
Note that the Series object itself contains a SeriesName property. The SeriesDrawing.SeriesName property allows the series name to be overridden within the chart. Setting this property does not affect the name in the Series object.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.PieSize
member.summary: Sets or gets the percentage of the grid area occupied by the pie chart for this series.
member.remarks: The PieSize property is useful when displaying more than one pie chart series at a time. For example, if there are two series, one of them can be large and have a donut hole, and the second can be smaller and display inside the donut hole of the first.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.DoughnutThickness
member.summary: Sets or gets the thickness (expressed as a percent of radius) of a 2D Pie chart's donut.
member.remarks:
Donut thickness is pie radius minus the radius of the hole. A donut thickness of 100% means the pie chart does not have a donut hole. A donut thickness of 50% means the pie chart will draw with a hole that is half the radius of the pie chart. This property is useful when displaying concentric pie charts inside one another.
This property applies only to 2D Pie charts.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.PieSmartLabelOffset
member.summary: Sets and gets the offset of the smart pie marker labels from the edge of the pie.
member.remarks:
On the right side of the pie this is the space from the ends of the left justified labels to the outermost pie slice. On the left side of the pie this is the space from the ends of the right justified labels to the outermost pie slice.
This space between the edge of the pie and the labels is the space where the label lines draw.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.PieSmartLabelMinFontSize
member.summary: Sets and gets the min font size for the smart label mode.
member.remarks: Note that if the current marker label font size is already less then this minimum size then the font will not be changed. Otherwise the algorithm that reduces the font size will not go below this specified size.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.PieExplodePercent
member.summary: Sets or gets the percent of pie radius that pie segments are exploded from the center of the pie.
member.remarks: Note that this property explodes all segments of a pie chart. To explode selected pie data points, use the SetDataPointExplode() method.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.PieUnits
member.summary: Sets or gets the pie units (percentage or data point value) for this series.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.PieLabelLocation
member.summary: Controls whether pie labels are inside or outside the pie wedges.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.PieLabelLineLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the length (expressed as a percentage of pie radius) of the line drawn from a pie wedge to its label.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.PieSmartLabelMidPoint
member.summary: Gets or Sets the mid-Point location of where the smart labels will draw the bend in the smart labels line.
member.remarks: This value is a percentage value between 0 and 100, with 0 being on the pie circumference and 100 being on the end of the labels. The mid-point is based on the outermost edge of the pie and the value specified in the property.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.PieLabelLine
member.summary: Gets the Line object that draws between (connects) the pie slices and pie labels.
member.remarks: See the class for detailed information about Line properties.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.PieLabelThreshold
member.summary: Sets or gets the threshold that determines how small a pie segment must be before its label is extended radially from the pie segment.
member.remarks:
When pie segments are very small, there may not be sufficient space for outside labels to draw without overlapping neighboring labels. When this happens, it can help to rotate the labels of segments that are too small. This property defines "too small."
The property value is a percentage of the total pie. If a segment's portion of the pie is less than this percentage, the label is rotated such that it extends radially from the pie wedge.
Note that the setting for this property takes effect only when pie label location is outside.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.Pie3DRotation
member.summary: Sets and gets the number of degrees from vertical to rotate a 3D Pie.
member.remarks: This property is only applicable for 3D Pie charts. Valid values are 0 degrees (viewed from above) to 89 degrees (viewed from the side).

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.Pie3DThickness
member.summary: Sets or gets the thickness of a 3D Pie chart.
member.remarks:
The property value is a percentage of maximum thickness.
The resulting thickness will be effected by the rotation angle. The more the Pie is rotated back, the more visible its thickness will be.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.ImageMapUrl
member.summary: Sets or gets the URL to load when a marker in this series is clicked on.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawing.ImageMapExtraString
member.summary: Sets and gets an extra string to embed in the image map for elements of this series.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawingCollection
member.summary: Manages a collection of SeriesDrawing objects.
member.remarks: This class is simply a wrapper around the array list that contains the list of SeriesDrawing objects. Note that the Chart class contains the property which is of type SeriesDrawingCollection. The SeriesDrawingList and SeriesDrawingCollection are essentially the some thing.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawingCollection.GetSeriesDrawing(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the series wrapper at the specified index.
member.param: Zero-based index.
member.returns: SeriesDrawing object or null if index does not contain an object.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawingCollection.Add(System.Object)
member.summary: Overridden. Connects the SeriesDrawing object to internal structures.
member.remarks: You should not use this method directly. Instead, add a Series object to the chart via the chart's AddSeries() method. AddSeries() allocates a new SeriesDrawing object, places the Series object inside the SeriesDrawing object, and then calls this method to add the SeriesDrawing object to the chart's list.
member.param: SeriesDrawing object.
member.returns: Zero-based index of the object in the list.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawingCollection.WriteProperties(System.Xml.XmlDocument,GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TemplateFlags,System.String)
member.summary: Writes all the SeriesDrawing objects currently in the list out to XML.
member.param: The XmlDocument context used to create the new element node.
Template flags to control template writing. See .
The name that will be given to the element node.
member.returns: This method returns an XmlElement if properties were written. A null value is returned if there were no properties to write.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SeriesDrawingCollection.ReadProperties(System.Xml.XmlNode,GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TemplateFlags)
member.summary: Reads SeriesDrawing properties from an XMLNode and applies them to objects in the SeriesDrawingList.
member.remarks:
This method reads the SeriesDrawing object properties out of the XML Node and applies them to the existing SeriesDrawing objects in the chart. In other words, the properties from the first SeriesDrawing object in the XML Node are applied to the first SeriesDrawing object in the list; the properties from the second SeriesDrawing object in the XML Node are applied to the second SeriesDrawing object in the list; and so on.
Note that this function does NOT create new SeriesDrawing objects in the chart. It only applies properties to existing objects in the chart.
member.param: XmlNode that contains the chart properties.
Template flags to control template writing. See .

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CircularLighting
member.summary: Will draw a circular lighted region using the specified location and color.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SpecialEffectBase
member.summary: Special Effects allow for additional drawing on top of other drawings. An example is lighted regions on top of existing Backgrounds.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SpecialEffectBase.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an instance of this type.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SpecialEffectBase.#ctor(GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Border)

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SpecialEffectBase.Rectangle
member.summary: Sets or gets the rectangle structure that defines the boundary of the special effect.
member.remarks: If the value is Empty then the rectangle will be automatically determined by the Background or Border that the special effect applies to.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SpecialEffectBase.Name
member.summary: Sets or gets the name that can be used to identify the particular instance of this special effect, such as within a list.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SpecialEffectBase.ClipShape
member.summary: Sets or gets the shape to draw the special effect within.
member.remarks: No drawing is done outside the boundaries of the shape.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SpecialEffectBase.ClipBoundingRectangle
member.summary: Sets or gets the bounding rectangle that the clip area will fit within.
member.remarks: The ClipShape will always fit within the ClipBoundingRectangle.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SpecialEffectBase.ClipPath
member.summary: Sets or gets the GraphicsPath object that the clip area will fit within.
member.remarks: The ClipShape property will need to be set to Path for the ClipPath property to be used.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.SpecialEffectBase.ClipRegion
member.summary: Sets or gets the Region object that the clip area will fit within.
member.remarks: The ClipShape property will need to be set to Region for the ClipRegion property to be used.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CircularLighting.StartRadius
member.summary: Defines where our lighting will start from radially outward on the circle.
member.remarks: This value is a percent value from 0 to 100 percent. 0 signifies the circle center, as opposed to 100 signifying the circle's edge.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CircularLighting.EndRadius
member.summary: Defines where our lighting will end at radially outward on the circle.
member.remarks: This value is a percent value from 0 to 100 percent. 0 signifies the circle origin, as opposed to 100 signifying the circle's edge.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CircularLighting.StartAngle
member.summary: Defines the angle in degress of where our lighting will start.
member.remarks: This angle is in degrees, from 0 degrees to 359 degress on the circle.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CircularLighting.SweepAngle
member.summary: Defines how far the light will sweep, or span, from the Start Angle.
member.remarks: This angle is in degrees, from 0 degrees to 359 degress. 0 degrees would draw no light (0 length), whereas 359 degrees would draw a light that spanned around the entire circle.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CircularLighting.Color
member.summary: Defines the color of the light that will be drawn.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CircularLighting.Transparency
member.summary: Defines the transparency, how light or dark, the circular lighting will be drawn.
member.remarks: The Transparency is a value between 0 and 100. 100 is fully transparent and is invisible.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CircularLighting.Breaks
member.summary: Defines how many light breaks, or empty gaps, appear in the lighted region.
member.remarks: The corresponding property to Breaks is BreakSweep which defines the angle value of each lighting break, or each empty gap.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CircularLighting.BreakSweep
member.summary: Defines the length of each light break, or empty gap, measured in degrees.
member.remarks: The corresponding property to BreakSweep is Breaks, where Breaks needs to be greater than 0 in order for one to see a lighting break with the length of BreakSweep.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CircularLighting.EdgeColor
member.summary: Defines the color of the circular lighting edge, when EdgeColorEnabled is true.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CircularLighting.EdgeColorEnabled
member.summary: Defines whether or not to use the EdgeColor for the circular lighting.
member.remarks: If EdgeColorEnabled is false, then the single CircularLighting.Color value will be used for the entire circular lighting area.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.LightSpot
member.summary: Will draw a circle light spot using the specified location and colors.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.LightSpot.XPercent
member.summary: Assigns the x location of the center of the light spot.
member.remarks: This value is a percent value from 0 to 100 percent. 0 signifies the circle's center, whereas 100 signifies the circle's edge.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.LightSpot.YPercent
member.summary: Assigns the y location of the center of the light spot.
member.remarks: This value is a percent value from 0 to 100 percent. 0 signifies the circle's center, as opposed to 100 signifying the circle's edge.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.LightSpot.WidthPercent
member.summary: Assigns the light spot's width.

remarks.para: The width percent is a relative size of the Background or Border that the light spot is drawn on top of.

If the percent is 100 then it will span the width of the Background or Border, whereas a smaller size will not fully span the width, and a larger size will extend beyond the Background or Border width.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.LightSpot.HeightPercent
member.summary: Assigns the light spot's height.

remarks.para: The height percent is a relative size of the Background or Border that the light spot is drawn on top of.

If the percent is 100 then it will span the height of the Background or Border, whereas a smaller size will not fully span the height, and a larger size will extend beyond the Background or Border height.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.LightSpot.CenterColor
member.summary: Assigns the color of the center of the light spot.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.LightSpot.EdgeColor
member.summary: Assigns the color at the edge of the light spot.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularDiagonalLighting.Start
member.summary: Defines where our lighting will start from on the left side of the rectangle.
member.remarks: This value is a percent value from 0 to 100 percent. 0 signifies the left-most region, and 100 specifies the right-most region.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularDiagonalLighting.Distance
member.summary: Defines how far our lighting will extend from the Start.
member.remarks: This value is a percent value from 0 to 100 percent. 0 signifies that the lighting distance is nothing, whereas 100 specifies the entire region after the Start will be lighted

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularDiagonalLighting.DiagonalLightingStartPosition
member.summary: Defines if our diagonal lighting will start from the Top-Left or Bottom-Left.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularDiagonalLighting.Color
member.summary: Defines the color of the light that will be drawn.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularDiagonalLighting.Transparency
member.summary: Defines the transparency, how light or dark, the lighting will be drawn.
member.remarks: The Transparency is a value between 0 and 100. 100 is fully transparent and is invisible.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularDiagonalLighting.EdgeColor
member.summary: Defines the color of the rectangular diagonal lighting edge, when EdgeColorEnabled is true.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularDiagonalLighting.EdgeColorEnabled
member.summary: Defines whether or not to use the EdgeColor for the rectangular diagonal lighting.
member.remarks: If EdgeColorEnabled is false, then the single RectangularDiagonalLighting.Color value will be used for the entire rectangular diagonal lighting area.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularLighting
member.summary: Will draw a rectangular lighted region using the specified location and colors.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularLighting.XPercent
member.summary: Assigns the x location (left edge) of the rectangle.
member.remarks: This value is a percent value from 0 to 100 percent. 0 signifies the left edge of the Background or Border that the rectangular lighting is drawn within, as opposed to 100 signifying the right edge of the Background or Border.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularLighting.YPercent
member.summary: Assigns the y location (top edge) of the rectangle.
member.remarks: This value is a percent value from 0 to 100 percent. 0 signifies the top edge of the Background or Border that the rectangular lighting is drawn within, as opposed to 100 signifying the bottom edge of the Background or Border.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularLighting.WidthPercent
member.summary: Assigns the rectangle's width.

remarks.para: The width percent is a relative size of the Background or Border that the lighted rectangle is drawn on top of.

If the percent is 100 then the lighted rectangle will span the width of the Background or Border, whereas a smaller size will not fully span the width, and a larger size will extend beyond the Background or Border width.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularLighting.HeightPercent
member.summary: Assigns the rectangle's height.

remarks.para: The height percent is a relative size of the Background or Border that the lighted rectangle is drawn on top of.

If the percent is 100 then it will span the height of the Background or Border, whereas a smaller size will not fully span the height, and a larger size will extend beyond the Background or Border height.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularLighting.Color
member.summary: Defines the color of the light that will be drawn.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularLighting.Transparency
member.summary: Defines the transparency, how light or dark, the lighting will be drawn.
member.remarks: The Transparency is a value between 0 and 100. 100 is fully transparent and is invisible.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularLighting.EdgeColor
member.summary: Defines the color of the rectangular diagonal lighting edge, when EdgeColorEnabled is true.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.RectangularLighting.EdgeColorEnabled
member.summary: Defines whether or not to use the EdgeColor for the rectangular diagonal lighting.
member.remarks: If EdgeColorEnabled is false, then the single RectangularDiagonalLighting.Color value will be used for the entire rectangular diagonal lighting area.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Symbol
member.remarks: A symbol is not the same as a marker. For example, a data point on a bar chart may have a bar marker that draws from the data point down to the Xaxis. If symbols are turned on, then a symbol will also display at the top of the bar marker, centered around the data point. Different marker types determine the best location for displaying symbols when they are turned on.
member.summary: Draws symbols used with data point markers.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation
member.summary: Represents a movable text object that can be placed anywhere on the chart.
member.remarks: The Chart object contains an AnnotationList property. To add an Annotation object to a chart, simply allocate a new Annotation and add it to the chart's AnnotationList.

example.code: 'Create an annotation Dim ann As Annotation = New Annotation ann.Text = "Note this, world!" 'Add it to the chart Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AnnotationList.Add(ann)

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TextBase
member.summary: This is the base class for title and annotation objects. A text base object contains its own font, color, and other text properties and is also a visual chart object that is displayed and can be resized. It draws its text within its visual chart object bounds.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TextBase.AutoSizeFontBasedOnBoundingRect
member.summary: Recalculates the font size for the text object based on the text object's bounding rect.
member.remarks: This method is useful when programmatically changing the text in the text object. If the AutoSizeText property is set to true, the text will not resize until the bounding rect is resized or until this method is called.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TextBase.Text
member.summary: Sets or gets the text to display.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TextBase.TextFormat
member.summary: Gets a TextPainter object that controls the way the text is drawn.
member.remarks: See the TextPainter class for more information.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TextBase.Vertical
member.remarks: Set to true to draw the text vertically. This is different than rotating it 90 degrees. This property will stack the letters on top of each other.
member.summary: Controls whether the text is drawn vertically.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TextBase.AutoSizeText
member.remarks: Set to true to turn auto-sizing on. When auto-sizing is turned on, the text font will automatically resize based on the new size of the element's bounding box.
member.summary: Controls whether the font automatically resizes when the text element's bounding box resizes.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an instance of this type.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Constructs an instance of this type with the Name property set to the specified string.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation.CoupleToObject
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates the object to which an annotation is coupled.
member.remarks: Note: Web form appplications may need to call EnableAnnotationCoupling in the Page Load event. See for more information.

code.title: Adding a title to the legend
Adding a title to the legend

example.code: ' Place an annotation along the bottom edge of the ' legend, where it can serve as the legend title Dim ann As Annotation = New Annotation With ann .Text = "Legend" .Size = New System.Drawing.Size(60, 20) .CoupleToEdge = CoupleToEdge.Top .CoupleToObject = CoupleToObject.Legend End With With Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart .AnnotationList.Add(ann) .SetRelativeLocation(ann, .Legend, RelativeLocation.BottomMiddle) .SetRelativeLocation(.ChartTitle, .Grid, RelativeLocation.TopMiddle) End With

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation.CoupleToEdge
member.summary: Gets or sets a value inidicating which edge of an object an annotation is coupled to.
member.remarks: Note: Web form appplications may need to call EnableAnnotationCoupling in the Page Load event. See for more information.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation.TooltipText
member.summary: Gets or sets the text to display in the popup tooltip.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation.Name
member.summary: Gets or sets the name of the annotation.
member.remarks: The name text is not displayed but can be used to retrieve an annotation from the AnnotationList. See the example for the GetAnnotation method.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation.CalloutOn
member.summary: Turns callout mode on and off.
member.remarks:
Set to true to turn the callout mode on. When the mode is turned on, the annotation has a pointer extended from the annotation rectangle to the screen point specified by the CalloutPointX and CalloutPointY properties.
When callout mode is turned on, the annotation does not paint all the effects specified in the Border property. Instead, the annotation paints a simple border around the callout based on the current "simple" border settings.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation.CalloutPointX
member.summary: Sets or gets the X coordinate for the anchor point of the Callout.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation.CalloutPointY
member.summary: Sets or gets the Y coordinate for the anchor point of the Callout.
member.example: See the example for the CalloutPointX property.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation.CalloutAttachWidth
member.summary: Specifies the width of the Callout extension at the point where it joins the annotation rectangle.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.AnnotationCollection
member.summary: Manages a collection of annotation objects.
member.remarks: This class is simply a wrapper around the array list that contains the list of annotation objects. Note that the Chart class contains the property which is of type AnnotationCollection. The AnnotationList and AnnotationCollection are essentially the some thing.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.AnnotationCollection.Add(System.Object)
member.summary: Adds an Annotation object to the collection in the AnnotationList property.
member.remarks: This method is overridden for connecting the Annotaton object to internal structures.
member.returns: Index in the list of the added annotation.

example.code:
'Create an annotation Dim myNote As New Annotation myNote.Text = "Note this, world!"
'Add the annotation to the chart Dim noteIndex As Integer = Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AnnotationList.Add(myNote)
'Use the index to retrieve the text of the annotation MessageBox.Show(Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AnnotationList.GetAnnotation(noteIndex).Text)

member.param: Annotation object to add.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.AnnotationCollection.Remove(System.Object)
member.summary: Removes an Annotation from the collection in the AnnotationList property. The object passed in should be an Annotation object.
member.param: The Annotation object to remove from the AnnotationList.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.AnnotationCollection.SetAnnotationAt(System.Int32,GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Annotation)
member.summary: Sets the annotation at the specified index.
member.remarks: If an annotation exists at the specified index, it is replaced with the annotation passed as the second argument. If the index does not exist in the list, the annotation is added to the end of the list.
member.returns: Index in the list of the added annotation.

example.code:
'Create two annotations Dim annFirst As New Annotation annFirst.Text = "Hello!" Dim annSecond As New Annotation annSecond.Text = "Goodbye!"
'Add the first annotation to the chart Dim noteIndex As Integer = Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AnnotationList.Add(annFirst)
'Use the index to retrieve the text of the annotation MessageBox.Show(Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AnnotationList.GetAnnotation(noteIndex).Text)
'Replace the first annotation with the second annotation noteIndex = Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AnnotationList.SetAnnotationAt(noteIndex, annSecond)
'Use the index to retrieve the text of the annotation MessageBox.Show(Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AnnotationList.GetAnnotation(noteIndex).Text)

member.param: zero based index.
Annotation object to add to the AnnotationList.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.AnnotationCollection.GetAnnotation(System.Int32)
member.summary: Retrieves the annotation at the specified index in the AnnotationList.
member.returns: Annotation object or null if no annotation exists at the specified index.
member.remarks: See the example for the SetAnnotationAt method.
member.param: zero based index.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.AnnotationCollection.GetAnnotation(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves an annotation whose Name property matches the specified string.
member.remarks: This method searches the annotations in the chart's AnnotationList and returns the first one that contains the specified string in its Name property.
member.returns: Annotation object or null if not found.

example.code: 'Search for an annotation named "Waldo" Dim ann As Annotation = Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AnnotationList.GetAnnotation("Waldo") If (ann Is Nothing) Then MessageBox.Show("Annotation doesn't exist!") Else MessageBox.Show("Annotation Found. Text: " + ann.Text) End If

member.param: The name of the annotation to return.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.AnnotationCollection.RemoveAnnotation(System.Int32)
member.summary: Removes the annotation at the specified index in the AnnotationList.
member.remarks: To replace the annotation at a particular index with another annotation, call the SetAnnotationAt method.

code.title: Using an index to remove an annotation
Using an index to remove an annotation

example.code:
'Create an annotation Dim myNote As New Annotation
'Add the annotation to the chart Dim noteIndex As Integer = Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AnnotationList.Add(myNote) . . . 'Remove the annotation Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AnnotationList.RemoveAnnotation(noteIndex)

member.param: zero based index.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CoupleToObject
member.summary: Defines which object an annotation is coupled to.
member.remarks:
An annotation can be coupled to an edge of one and only one object. For example, an annotation can be coupled to the bottom edge of the chart title. Whenever the chart title moves or resizes, the coupled annotation will move with it, maintaining the same distance from the bottom edge of the chart title object.
Note that multiple annotations can be coupled to the same edge of an object.

member.summary: The annotation is not coupled.

member.name: F:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CoupleToObject.Legend
member.summary: The annotation is coupled to the Legend.

member.summary: Defines which edge of an object an annotation is coupled to.

member.summary: The annotation is not coupled.

member.name: F:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CoupleToEdge.Left
member.summary: The annotation is coupled to the Chart Title.

member.name: F:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CoupleToEdge.Right
member.summary: The annotation is coupled to the Grid.

member.name: F:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.CoupleToEdge.Top

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.BorderLabel
member.summary: A border label is a non-movable text object that can be displayed within some types of VisualChartObject classes, such as Grid and Device objects.

member.summary: Constructs an instance of this type.

member.summary: Constructs an instance of this type with the Name property set to the specified string.

member.summary: Paints the border label based on the current property settings.
member.param: PaintEventArgs

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.BorderLabel.Name
member.summary: Sets and gets the name of the label.
member.remarks: The name is not displayed but can be used to retrieve a border label from the BorderLabelList.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.BorderLabel.Text
member.summary: Sets or gets the text displayed in the label.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.BorderLabel.TextFormat
member.summary: Gets a TextPainter object that controls the way the text is drawn.
member.remarks: See the class for more information.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.BorderLabel.RelativeLocation
member.summary: This value determines the location of the label relative to one of the four sides of the object in which it is drawn.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.BorderLabel.OffsetTopBottom
member.summary: Sets and gets the offset from the top or bottom edge of the label's text box.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.BorderLabel.OffsetLeftRight
member.summary: Sets and gets the offset from the left or right edge of the label's text box.
member.remarks: The setting for this property becomes relevant only when the RelativeLocation property of the border label is set to a location other than the middle (LeftMiddle, RightMiddle, TopMiddle, BottomMiddle).

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.BorderLabel.IsVisible
member.summary: Specifies whether the label is visible.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.BorderLabel.FlipText
member.summary: Controls whether the text should be rotated 180 degrees.
member.remarks:
Setting the FlipText property to true rotates the label's text 180 degrees.
This property is particularly useful for border labels positioned along the right or left sides of an object. For example, by default a label on the right side of an object reads from top down. Setting the FlipText property to true causes the label to read from bottom up.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.BorderLabel.VisualChartObject
member.summary: Sets or gets a reference to the VisualChartObject on which the label draws.

member.remarks: The base constructor requires the SeriesComponent the trend uses when calculating trend data.

member.summary: Gets the Line object that draws trend lines. This property exists to provide access to the properties and methods of the underlying Line object.

member.summary: Gets the Trend Type of this trend object.
member.remarks: Refer to the enumeration for details.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendBase.IsCalculated
member.remarks: Returns true if the trend data has been calculated. Note that the grid will make sure that this data is calculated for the first time if the user has not already forced a calculation via the series. Once a trend is allocated it can be added to a specific SeriesDrawing object via the SeriesDrawing.AddTrend() method. A specific instance of a trend should be added to one and only one SeriesDrawing object. Once attached to that SeriesDrawing object the trend object will calculate the trend results and buffer that data for later use.
member.summary: Indicates if trend data has been calculated for the first time.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendExponentialOne
member.summary: Exponential One Trend.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendVariableOrderPolynomial
member.summary: This is the base class for the Variable Order Polynomial Type trends. The general equation for a polynomial order trend is: Y = a + b * (x) + c * (x ^ 2) + d * (x ^ 3) + e * (x ^ 4) + f * (x ^ 5) + ... The degree to which X gets raised to depends on the degree property. A maximum degree of 9 is allowed.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendVariableOrderPolynomial.#ctor(GraphicsServer.GSNet.SeriesData.SeriesComponent,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructor.
member.param: SeriesComponent used for trend calculataions.

Degrees of the polynomial. The maximum degree allowed is nine (a 9th order polynomial). Any degree value higher than nine will be reset to the value of 9. If a best fit curve is desired (a curve passing through all your data points), use a instead of a .

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendVariableOrderPolynomial.Coefficients
member.summary: An array containing the Coefficients of the Regression equation. These can be used to find the underlying equation. For example, assume the trend's equation is: Y = a + b * X + c * (X ^ 2). Then to calculate the real equation substitute the Coefficents in for the "a, b, c" values: Coefficients[0] = a Coefficients[1] = b Coefficients[2] = c Thus the new equation would be: Y = Coefficients[0] + Coefficients[1] * X + Coefficients[2] * (X ^ 2)

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendExponentialOne.#ctor(GraphicsServer.GSNet.SeriesData.SeriesComponent)

member.param: SeriesComponent used for trend calculataions.

member.summary: Exponential One Trend. The equation for this trend is: Y = a * exp(b * x).

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendMean
member.summary: Draws a line indicating the mean value of all points in a data series.

remarks.para: A TrendMean object draws a line indicating the mean value of a specified component of all points in a particular data series shown on the chart. A SeriesComponent (such as SeriesComponent.Y) is specified in the constructor.
Note: When the trend object calculates a mean, it excludes any data points that are hidden (for example, by calling the SeriesDrawing.HideDataPoint method).
To associate the mean line with a data series, you must add it to the SeriesDrawing object for the series.
You can control drawing characteristics of the line by setting properties of the Line object accessed via TrendMean.LineProperties.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendMean.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an instance of this type.

member.summary: Constructs an instance of this type.
member.param: used for trend calculations.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendMean.Mean
member.summary: Gets the calculated mean value.
member.remarks: The mean value is not calculated until the TrendMean object has been added to a SeriesDrawing object and its drawing has been rendered by calling one of the chart's reconciliation methods such as RecalcLayout().

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendMean.Trendtype
member.summary: Gets the Trend Type this object represents.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendMinMax
member.summary: Draws two lines representing the minimum and maximum values of a series.

remarks.para: A TrendMinMax object draws lines representing the minimum and maximum values of a particular series of the chart. You can control drawing characteristics of the lines by setting properties of the Line object accessed via TrendMinMax.LineProperties.

After you create a TrendMinMax object, you must associate it with a data series by adding it to the SeriesDrawing object associated with the series. A series can have more than one trend line. You can, for example, create a TrendMinMax object and a TrendMean object, and add them both to the same SeriesDrawing object.

Number of points to average.

param.name: tension
param.para: Determines the shape of the curve. If the value is 0.0F, this method draws straight line segments to connect the points. Usually, the tension parameter is less than or equal to 1.0F. Values over 1.0F produce unusual results.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendMovingAvgBase.Tension
member.summary: Gets and sets the tension for the spline fit.

remarks.para: Tension determines the shape of the curve. If the value is 0.0F, this method draws straight line segments to connect the points. Usually, the tension parameter is less than or equal to 1.0F. Values over 1.0F produce unusual results.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendMovingAvgBase.NumberPtsToAvg
member.summary: Gets and sets the number of points to average.
member.remarks: A moving average is calculated by dividing a series of data points into sets of consecutive points and then averaging the values in each set. This property determines how many points are in each set.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendMovingAvgBase.AveragePoints
member.summary: Gets an array of points to average.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendMovingAvgBeg
member.summary: Draws a moving average line for a data series by plotting the average at the first point of each set of data points.

remarks.para: A TrendMovingAvgBeg object creates sets of n points within a series. The specified component values of data points (for example, the Y values) in each set are averaged, and the averaged value is drawn at the first point of the set. This procedure is repeated for all sets of n points in the series, and the averaged values are connected with lines.

After you create a TrendMovingAvgBeg object, you must add it to the SeriesDrawing object associated with a particular data series on the chart. A series can be associated with more than one trend line.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendMovingAvgBeg.#ctor(GraphicsServer.GSNet.SeriesData.SeriesComponent,System.Int32)
member.summary: Constructs an instance of this type.
member.param: SeriesComponent used for trend calculations.
Number of points to average.

remarks.para: A TrendMovingAvgEnd object creates sets of n points within a series. The specified component values of data points (for example, the Y values) in each set are averaged, and the averaged value is drawn at the last point of the set. This procedure is repeated for all sets of n points in the series, and the averaged values are connected with lines.

After you create a TrendMovingAvgEnd object, you must add it to the SeriesDrawing object associated with a particular data series on the chart. A series can be associated with more than one trend line.

Number of points to average.

param.name: tension

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendMovingAvgMid
member.summary: Draws a moving average line for a data series by plotting the average at the mid-point of each set of data points.

remarks.para: A TrendMovingAvgMid object creates sets of n points within a series. The specified component values of data points (for example, the Y values) in each set are averaged, and the averaged value is drawn at the mid-point of the set. This procedure is repeated for all sets of n points in the series, and the averaged values are connected with lines.

After you create a TrendMovingAvgMid object, you must add it to the SeriesDrawing object associated with a particular data series on the chart. A series can be associated with more than one trend line. You can, for example, create moving average trends with different intervals and add them to the same SeriesDrawing object. Or you can create other types of Trend objects and add them all to the same SeriesDrawing object.

You can also add the same TrendMovingAvgMid object to more than one series, but this is not recommended because each line would have the same drawing characteristics and thus not be easily distinquished from moving averages for other series.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendStandardDeviation
member.summary: Draws standard deviation lines.

remarks.para: A TrendStandardDeviation object draws two lines related to the values of a particular data series. One line is a specified number of standard deviations above the mean, the other line is the same number of standard deviations below the mean. You can specify the number of standard deviations in the constructor or by setting the NumberOfDevs property.

After creating a TrendStandardDeviation object you must associate it with a data series by adding it to a SeriesDrawing object in the chart's SeriesDrawingList. Any number of trend objects can be added to a particular SeriesDrawing object.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendStandardDeviation.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an instance of this type.

member.summary: Constructs an instance of this type.

member.summary: Constructs an instance of this type.
member.param: Number of standard deviations to use in plotting the lines.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendStandardDeviation.StandardDeviation
member.summary: Gets the standard deviation.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendStandardDeviation.Mean
member.summary: Gets the calculated mean value.
member.remarks: The mean value is not calculated until the trend object has been added to the chart and series data has been reconciled by calling, for example, the ReconcileDataAndRecalc method.

member.name: P:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.TrendStandardDeviation.NumberOfDevs
member.summary: Gets and sets the number of standard deviations to use in plotting the lines.

remarks.para: Two lines are drawn, one above the mean, the other below. This property controls how many standard deviations the lines are drawn above and below the mean.

Note: When NumberOfDevs is greater than 1, one or both lines can fall above or below the margins of the grid. By default, anything drawn beyond the grid's margins is clipped. You can turn clipping off by setting the Grid.ClipToTopMargin and Grid.ClipToBottomMargin properties.

member.name: T:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart
member.summary: This class exposes all the properties, methods, and events of the Graphics Server .NET Chart object.
member.remarks: The Chart object has been wrapped inside a custom Windows user control and a Web control to facilitate its use in Windows forms and Web forms. However, you can also use the object directly within your code.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.#ctor
member.summary: Constructs an instance of the Chart class.
member.remarks: Creates grid, legend, title, background, and border objects; creates empty annotation and series lists; and defaults to a Line2D chart type.

member.summary: Returns the selected object in the chart if an object is selected. Otherwise null is returned.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.EnableAnnotationCoupling
member.summary: Enables annotation coupling in a Web Forms application.
member.remarks:
This method exists due to a timing problem. When the Web chart control initializes during the Page Load event, it must turn off annotation coupling in order to read in settings for size and location properties. Once initial settings have been read in, the initialization process completes, and annotation coupling, unfortunately, remains off.
This is not a problem if there is no user interaction and chart object sizes and locations do not change. However, if there is user interaction and annotation coupling is off, coupled annotations will not properly follow the object to which they are coupled. They will behave as if they were not coupled.
The cure is to call EnableAnnotationCoupling() inside the Web form's Page Load event. This ensures that coupling is turned back on and that annotations move when the objects to which they are coupled move.

member.remarks: Auto-binding is a quick and easy way to create category-based charts. This and other auto-binding methods do all the work involved in creating DataProvider and Series objects, binding the Y component of the series to the data provider, and adding the series to the chart.
member.param: The DataView that contains the data to bind.
A string array of field names.
member.exception: One or more field names do not exist in the DataView.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.AddSeries(GraphicsServer.GSNet.SeriesData.Series)
member.summary: Adds a series to the chart.
member.remarks:
The return value is the index of the series in the chart and can be used to reference that series later.
Note that when a series is added to a chart, it is wrapped inside of a SeriesDrawing object. See the SeriesDrawing class for more information.
member.returns: Zero-based index of the SeriesDrawing object in the SeriesDrawingList.

example.para: The code fragment below creates two new Series objects loaded with random data, an additional Series object loaded with category labels, and adds all three to a chart. Notice that only the data series are added by calling the AddSeries method. The label series is simply assigned to the LabelSeries property of the X axis.

It is also worth pointing out that before adding the new Series objects, the example code removes the two dummy series created at design time as an aide to design. If we had omittted the call to RemoveAllSeries(), the chart would end up with four data series rather than two.
example.code:
'Load random data for apple sales into a series Dim apples As New Series apples.RandomizeComponent(SeriesComponent.Y, 9, 46, 237) apples.SeriesName = "Apples"
'Load random data for orange sales into a series Dim oranges As New Series oranges.RandomizeComponent(SeriesComponent.Y, 9, 17, 193) oranges.SeriesName = "Oranges"
'Load category (X axis) labels into a series Dim labels As New Series Dim dt As New System.Globalization.DateTimeFormatInfo Dim i As Integer For i = 1 To 12 'Set label to the name of a month labels.SetValue(SeriesComponent.Label, i - 1, dt.GetAbbreviatedMonthName(i)) Next
With Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart 'Remove the dummy series created at design time .RemoveAllSeries()
'Add the new data series to the chart Dim appleIndex As Integer = .AddSeries(apples) Dim orangeIndex As Integer = .AddSeries(oranges)
'Add category labels .Grid.AxisX.LabelSeries = labels End With

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.ReplaceSeries(System.Int32,GraphicsServer.GSNet.SeriesData.Series)
member.summary: Replaces the series object for an existing series in the chart.
member.remarks:
If a series does not exist at the specified index, the replacement will fail. The return value indicates whether or not the replacement was successful.
Note that when a series is first added to a chart, it is wrapped inside of a SeriesDrawing object. The SeriesDrawing object carries all the drawing properties for a series within the chart. See the SeriesDrawing class for more information.
Using this method to swap a series of data within an existing SeriesDrawing object preserves all the original drawing properties. This method is useful for developers who create multiple random series objects at design-time in order to set up all the drawing properties within the design-time environment. Then at run time the developer simply needs to create the new series objects and replace the random series already in the chart.
member.returns: Returns true if the series was successfully replaced.

member.summary: Calling this method will reapply all the default properties in the SeriesDrawing object to each SeriesDrawing object currently in the SeriesDrawingList.
member.remarks: Call this method after loading a template into the chart object. When a template is loaded into the chart, the chart will not force the existing SeriesDrawing objects to reload their properties based on the SeriesDefault properties read in from the template. Calling this method will ensure that the existing SeriesDrawing objects in the chart get refreshed with the SeriesDefaults from the template.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.BeginInit
member.summary: Temporarily suspends Reconcile and RecalcLayout operations.
member.remarks:
This method implements the ISupportInitialize.BeginInit interface method. BeginInit() disables any Reconcile or RecalcLayout operation that might occur due to setting properties in the chart. EndInit() re-enables Reconcile and RecalcLayout operations.
Use both methods together for temporarily disabling Reconcile and RecalcLayout operations while doing a block of property setting operations.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.EndInit
member.summary: See BeginInit().

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.ReconcileAndRecalcAll
member.summary: Reconciles series data with the active ChartType, resets series drawing characteristics to the default for the active ChartType, recalculates the layout, and redraws the chart.
member.remarks:
This method is called internally by Graphics Server each time the value of the ChartType property changes. You should not call it directly from your code; it will reset chart display properties to the defaults for the selected ChartType.
If you have modified data within any of the chart's attached Series, call the ReconcileDataAndRecalc() method to update the display. If you have modified characteristics of drawing objects on the chart, call the RecalcLayout() method.
There are two concepts here: reconciling series data and reconciling SeriesDrawing display properties. Reconciling data is a non-destructive process that simply determines if an attached series contains the proper data components to be displayed for the active ChartType. (For example, if the active ChartType is Range2D, it checks to see that there are both High and Low series components.) During the process of reconciling data, each SeriesDrawing object also walks all components within the attached Series object and buffers up the maximum number of data points across those components for later use.
In contrast, reconciling SeriesDrawing display properties is a destructive process. SeriesDrawing properties are modified to suit the rules of the active ChartType. For example, each time you change the chart type you will notice that the MarkerType property on the SeriesDrawing objects change to reflect the active ChartType. Other properties may be modified as well. This is why you may not want to call this method directly. The ReconcileDataAndRecalc() method and the RecalcLayout() method are usually better choices.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.ReconcileDataAndRecalc
member.summary: Reconciles series data with the active ChartType, recalculates the layout, and redraws the chart.
member.remarks:
This method should be called any time data has been manipulated in any of the attached Series. (Remember that Series are wrapped inside the SeriesDrawing object when attached to the chart.) This method will scan all the attached Series and validate they are still valid to display on the active ChartType. It also walks all attached Series and buffers up the total data point count across the active Series. This is the definition of reconciling the data based on the active chart type. It is non-destructive.
Note that this method is different from the ReconcileAndRecalcAll() method, which reconciles the data but also reconciles the display properties on the SeriesDrawing object. Reconciling the display properties is a destructive process.
Also note that RecalcLayout() will be called within this method.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.ReconcileMarkerConditions
member.summary: Walks each attached SeriesDrawing object and tells it to run the attached marker condition tests.
member.remarks: Note that this method is lightweight and does not cause any data or property reconciliation to take place.

example.code:
' Assume there are two created series and add them to the chart Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AddSeries(s1) Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.AddSeries(s2)
' Next create the check object Dim check As LessThanYCheck = New LessThanYCheck(100) ' Set the color if the condition passes check.MarkerFill.Color = Color.Yellow ' Add the condition to the series drawing objects Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.GetSeriesDrawing(0).AddMarkerCondition(check) Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.GetSeriesDrawing(1).AddMarkerCondition(check) ' Now tell the chart to run the tests and display the results Me.GsNetWinChart1.Chart.ReconcileMarkerConditions()

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.ReconcileLineConditions
member.summary: Walks each attached SeriesDrawing object and tells it to run the attached line condition tests.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.ReconcileDataAndRecalcForCodeGen
member.summary: This method exists to support the code generation sequence in the win forms InitializeComponents() method. It should not be used directly in code.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.ReconcileAllDataForActiveChartType
member.summary: Reconciles all series data with the current chart type.
member.remarks: Call this method, then call RecalcLayout to generate the drawing objects for the grid. Note that once this method is called, the properties on the series and the active axis can be modified.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.RecalcLayout
member.summary: Recalculates the axis coordinate system, regenerates all drawing objects in the grid, updates the legend, and redraws the chart.
member.remarks:
At design time, when you modify a chart property, the chart is redrawn to display the result. This encourages interactive experimentation. The same behavior carries over to run time when a user interactively changes properties through the property window or property pages. However, it is not desirable to have the chart update after every modification when you set properties in code. In this case, drawing objects on screen are not updated when you change property values. Once you have modified all the properties that you intend to set, call the RecalcLayout() method to update the chart's display.
Note that if data has been modified within any of the attached Series, calling this method may not properly show the results of the updated data. Instead call the ReconcileDataAndRecalc() method.

member.remarks: This routine will print the chart at the specified point. The chart will aslo be resize based on the specified size before printing. After the chart is printed the original size of the chart will be reset.
member.param: The printing arguments
The point to offset the printing of the chart on the page.
The size to print the chart.

member.remarks: This routine will print the chart at the specified point. The current chart size will be used when printing the chart.
member.param: The printing arguments
The point to offset the printing of the chart on the page.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.QuickLayout(GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.QuickLayoutType)
member.summary: Lay out the chart using a canned quick layout format.
member.remarks: This method uses one of the canned layouts from the QuickLayoutType enumeration. For more precise control over a quick layout, use the QuickLayoutData class.
member.param: Defines which canned quick layout to apply.

member.name: M:GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.Chart.QuickLayout(GraphicsServer.GSNet.Charting.QuickLayoutData)
